Crimes.Violation_Type: Immigration violation due to overstaying authorized period
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister must defer deportation under s. 52(1)(a) of the Immigration Act when conflicting with a probation order
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 52(1)(a) and (b) of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant had a valid deportation order and a probation order; probation order did not require presence in Canada or court attendance
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Writ of Prohibition to prevent execution of deportation order
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Deportation order does not violate s. 52(1)(a) as probation order does not mandate presence in Canada
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Complied with probation conditions but remained beyond visa validity
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Conflict between deportation order and active probation order
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Whether judicial order explicitly requires individual’s presence in Canada
Crimes.Applicable_Legislation: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 52
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of administrative decision on deferral of removal
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of explicit requirement in probation order for applicant's presence in Canada
Crimes.Cause_Description: Conflict between deportation and probation orders raised question on applicability of s. 52
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration status violation due to overstaying visa
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to maintain legal immigration status
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Probation order did not constitute a judicial order that would bar removal under s. 52(1)(a)
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Copy of probation order, deportation order, statutory provisions
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 52(1)(a) and (1)(b) of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Application_Basis: Request to prohibit enforcement of deportation based on ongoing probation
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Section 52(1)(a): removal order cannot be executed if it contravenes a judicial order

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Conflict between immigration enforcement and criminal supervision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether s. 52 of the Immigration Act obligates deferral of deportation due to a probation order
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 52(1)(a) and (1)(b) of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of deportation order execution
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Court assessed terms of probation order for mandatory presence requirements
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed; deportation allowed to proceed
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate conflict with judicial order under s. 52
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Not applicable – issue was legal interpretation, not witness credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: s. 52(1)(a) only applies if removal violates a judicial order requiring presence
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Availability of writ of prohibition to challenge deportation timing
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Execution of deportation order may interfere with probation compliance
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed – no statutory obligation to defer
Crimes.Judicial_Review_Outcome: Application for writ of prohibition dismissed
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: No breach of procedural fairness found
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Text of probation order, deportation order, statutory framework
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Intersection of criminal sentencing and immigration enforcement
Crimes.Applicant_Challenge: Argued that deportation during probation period undermines court’s order
Crimes.Court_Result: Deportation order not stayed; removal permitted
Crimes.Legal_Rule_Source: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 52
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Compliance with probation without need for continued presence
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Writ of Prohibition to halt deportation
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Prevention of removal until probation completion
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Individual under probation supervision and subject to deportation
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 52(1)(a) and (1)(b) of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Overstaying visa leading to deportation order
Crimes.Jurisdiction: Federal Court – national jurisdiction over immigration matters
